quick quick introduction about myself like was mentioned I come from mode know

we want to be able to build the kind of tooling on top of that to actually extract that and so we have a lot of

why invest in data like why does this matter at all if you're a startup why should you why should you care I want I
think like this is a pretty like it's a pretty well accepted thing at this point this is a quote from Sequoia Capital
wrote of this big series of articles about why startups should invest in data their overall doujin point was it's a
must have it's not an afterthought it's something that you should do along with when you set up your email and you set up ways to communicate with your
customers and you set up your infrastructure for building your product it's just kind of part of part of that ecosystem now and so I think a lot of
people kind of accepted that but it's still kind of useful sometimes to step back and say like what is it that I actually get out of this like what's the
real value potentially for me so there's a few examples of this I think that are that are sort of the non-obvious ones or
ones that there's good to highlight for kind of tangible examples of ways to get value out of data one of those is when
you're an early-stage company having data is often the best way to prioritize and and as early-stage companies like
time is the most important thing you can't really waste time making bad decisions or focusing on areas that
don't matter and so data is often a really good way to be able to prioritize those most important things so that you
take the very limited resources you have and use them use them wisely like an obvious example of this is say that
you're building a product where people go to a website and try to purchase something if you look at a funnel which
this is kind of an example of what a funnel might look like you want to build a focus on the area of the funnel where where people are dropping off you want
to be able to know like which part of this is the one that actually matters that you may think oh I need to go from visiting website to signing up for a
trial we really need to spend a lot of time helping people get into a trial but it does look like that's actually the problem here it's actually they're not entering
credit cards and so that very much changes the the decisions you make and you can't really do this without having good visibility to how people are
actually using your product to give them a concrete example of this that's kind of an easy example that that is sort of
obvious in some ways but a more concrete example of this that actually had a real impact on on a customer of ours so there
was this company called the knot they a lot of people may not be familiar with it but you've probably used it it's the
the company that hosts websites for people who have having weddings so if you go to a like Dylann love sharon calm
when your friends get married that website is often hosted by the knot they support a lot of the the sort of
infrastructure around that and so they actually a few years ago released a mobile app and they were like because
we're like everybody else said hey Mobile is the future here we want to make sure that then when people are setting up these websites they can do it in a really great way for for people on
their phones so they released this mobile app and when they first released it they weren't getting a whole lot of traction and they were like running into
problems figuring out what was gonna make it successful and so they were trying to spend a bunch of resources to
decide like hey where do we invest our feature development what area do we focus on and so they never really found
anything that's sticked or that stuck until they started looking into their data and then they made this this chart
this was one of the ways they try to explore that data and the specifics of this visualization aren't as important
is this this like brown spike down here what this kind of brown thing in the
bottom right is is it was representing there's a bunch of people who come to their their mobile app and go to one
page and one page only and they would do that consistently and so they dug into that and they realized this one page
that they go to was actually like the countdown to your wedding so it'd be like you're getting married in 83 days
you're getting married in 82 days and some people kept going back to it every day and what they were doing was they're taking screenshots of that page and then
like posting it on Instagram being like oh my god I'm getting married 82 days and so they realized because of that
they actually had an opportunity to really lean into that and they made that page much better for that they made it easier for you to like put a background
picture of you and whoever you're marrying on there they made it easy for you to be able to share it over social media they like really found ways to
lean into that you or behavior that they had no idea that's what was going to happen it certainly wasn't the intention but by being able
to see that in their data they could make this decision that ultimately made the app much stickier so as a start-up
that's that's the kind of thing you want to be to discovery you want to go to find these these ways that people are using your products and be able to
really lean on those rather than kind of throwing throwing noodles at wall and seeing what sticks a second part of this
that one of the things that data can be really useful for for for early-stage companies is it's a critical part of fundraising and as was mentioned I gave
a talk on this about a month ago here about a lot of the pieces that go into that these are some of the the sort of
key metrics that often drive fundraising proposals and fundraising pitches for for sort of seed in series a startups
and oftentimes you're not going to actually be able to close that round unless you have this information and
being able to collect this and report on it well and do it do it efficiently depends on your your data being in a
good place and you can do that a lot better with a stronger data infrastructure so data is a really key part of a fundraising which for better
or for worse is often a key part of building a growing business and finally this doesn't get easier the
the later you go if it's something kind of punt on now and say hey we'll get to that well we have a core product to
focus on we have other things to focus on and we'll worry about data once we get there or once we once we need it
you're actually setting yourself up for a much harder problem down the road and as an example of that like what
often we see happening when people don't tend to invest in this early is they'll essentially set something up very early
with like Google Analytics they'll start looking at just traffic through something like that they'll start realizing hey we want to ask a little
bit richer questions what Google Analytics can do they'll start putting stuff in Excel it's something to be managing like financial numbers in Excel
they'll get fed up with sharing things over email because sharing things over email is a pain so they'll start putting
it in Google sheets and know they have some stuff in Excel because there's somebody who came from an investment bank that loves Excel and hates Google sheets and Google sheets has half that
information now and then they'll start like collecting payment data from stripe and stripe has their own data that they
have like in the stripe portal that people will look at and some engineer will get fed up with that and we'll
build like a dashboard that's their own little custom dashboard that's pulling data from all these other sources and
then you'll start putting data into Salesforce because that's where you keep track of like data and at some point you have this entire ecosystem but this is where all
your data lives in all these different places and some board member will come along and say how much money did you make last quarter and it'll be really
hard to answer and you'll have to be like well what does this excel file say Google Analytics says one thing Salesforce says this other thing this
one engineer swears by the dashboard that he built or she built stripe says something totally different and you're
like I have no idea what we actually made it's a huge pain you have to dig yourself out of it and you have all these different places that everybody
relies on a different thing and you've got to figure out some way to make this all work and you don't want to be in that situation if you set this up first
then you have to worry about this you can build like a consistent pipeline where everybody looks for the same information in the same place and then
when you have this board member ask you how much money you make you can everybody can give them a consistent answer so yeah so a lot of good reasons
to do this it's also something that you can do very quickly it's not something
takes a lot of time it's not something that's like a huge investment to make you could do it quickly you can do it reasonably cheaply the things that I'm

tiers that you basically have to pay nothing for but on net I think you can
get away with doing this for and on the order of a few grand a year and that can scale up to something much bigger like
as your business grows you can again scale that to fit your business so there's nothing really any really any
reason not to do it and there's a lot of good good reasons to so what is it like
what is it that you'd actually want to set up what is that that modern data stack actually look like so I can kind of outline this pretty quickly of some
of the different pieces of it and and you'll hear different things from different folks other people have like slightly different perspectives on how
they should build this but fundamentally this is what what it is that you're trying to build on the far left of this
you have different data sources so you have things like website traffic you have application data so if you're building like a web app there's often a
database that is the thing behind that web app it's like the source of truth for when somebody signs up that user
gets created in database somewhere or it's it's your orders database or something that's like powering your
business and nowadays you often have a lot of SAS apps you have things like Salesforce or Marketo or intercom
sonna or stripe or all these other things that are critical to the operations of your business and contain
in varying degrees the sources of truth of what's happening Salesforce may be the source of truth for your sales team
stripe may kind of be the source of truth for your revenue but like not quite because maybe you're doing refunds
somewhere else or something like that but but you have all these applications to pull things together typically then
what you want to do is you want to centralize that into into a single warehouse so you have one kind of point that all of this data gets funneled into
that gives you the ability not just to have it centralized and sort of accessible via one entry point but also
lets you combine it it lets you answer questions that are across the how does something from stripe combine with my
tickets that come in through Zendesk with the the website traffic that we're getting on our help page so you can able
to combine that and you have some platform that sits on top of your warehouse like a bi or analytics platform that lets you actually ask
those questions and interface with that data in a reasonable way and then lets you share those insights out to other folks
so the centralized warehouse this is kind of the hub of it it is place that hosts all of your data the other thing
you want to be able to do is you want to build pipelines so you have pipelines that feed in from these applications into that warehouse and then you have
this this platform for visualizing and sharing data so what is the way that you
do this like there's there's essentially a few steps the first step is really setting up the warehouse and unlike a

it's something that's important there are a lot of good options out there obviously given where we are redshift is

when we recommend this to new folks why is redshift one of the ones that that we tend to think works very well there's
actually a few reasons for that then we think it's a sort of a great choice here one is that it's really easy to set up
and maintain so a good part of this is like an important part of this system is you want it to be low cost if you're a

pretty well here too so once you have a database the second thing you want to do

else there's kind of three major categories of different sources
of data one is this web traffic data the second one are these application databases which are essentially you have
a Postgres database or my sequel database or something else that's actually powering your applications and then you have these SAS products that
that have databases behind them but you don't have access to that that you can interface with with stripes database you
have to interface with it through api's and things like that for getting data out of out of from web traffic into into
your warehouse there's a few options one that we typically recommend is a tool called segments so segment does a number
of different things but at its core what segments is is this kind of routing layer that lets you log events on your
website or from your your mobile apps or from even the sort of server side logging and dispense it out to to other
applications you can write it out to add tracking software or to tools like
Salesforce or Marketo but you can also write it into databases and they have an integration with redshift they also
support integrations with other other major cloud providers as well but by instrumenting segment which all it takes
is like adding something like this to your website when people take actions they have this very nice sort of logging
API by instrumenting segment you can then dispatch that data into and these are tools as well as the to your
database so if you want to have all of these event logs immediately funneled into into redshift or your other
warehouses you can do that and it all kind of manages it for you it takes care a lot of the the infrastructure pieces
of how does it handle failures how does it handle retries gives you some nice dashboards into how those events are
actually being processed if you don't want to pay for it there's parts of this are also open source they have open

really important for early-stage companies to go to do this well one is there's no as an initial setup cost that
if you're trying to build like a bi application especially as an early-stage company you don't actually put a lot of investment into sort of
building that entire application that you want to go to ask questions of it very quickly you're having to make decisions quickly and you'll often have
like oh we have an hour to try to figure this thing out and engineer wants to be able to move forward on it let's do some

to like build an entire sort of model on top of that before you can actually ask questions so we actually wrote a whole

done and so mode lets you just be able to get stuff started right away again you can just fill out connections to a

view should look like you want to be able to look at say you're trying to debug something you want to be able to look at exactly what happened to this
person you want to look at logs for a specific user some customer might write in because they saw something really funky and you want to be able to see
like exactly what they did and that raw level data or row level data is very important and so we built node in such a
way that actually provides access to that again it's essentially just a query sequel client so you can be able to do
whatever you want on that that row level data again which can be very valuable for for early-stage company and finally
one of the most important things here is it's very fast to share that that you want to have a tool that's easy to distribute to other people around your

when should i up for a data Lake instead of a data warehouse so in some ways you
don't have to make that choice it depends on the problem that you have a lot of folks that we know especially
when they run into scale problems which tends to be the reasons that people choose a data Lake in the first place is they use something like Athena or
snowflake which is AWS competitor that separates compute from storage essentially what that lets you do is it
lets you dump a bunch of data into s3 so you just like dump all of your data into kind of an unstructured way in s3 then
you have a compute layer that sits on top of that that handles defining your schema and then it handles when you're
querying it so you don't actually up to pay for the storage of this like massive amount of log data if you're trying to write something like cloud watch for
instance which generates a ton of data dumping it into s3 and then putting like Athena on top of that is often a pretty good solution AWS has ways to be able to
kind of combine those so for instance if you have a bunch of data in s3 which can be your data Lake they have a service
called spectrum which is essentially like redshift it's querying s3 through redshift so
spectrum is a way where where you actually can interface with it as though it is the same as redshift you can keep some data in redshift you can keep some
data in s3 in this data Lake and then spectrum sort of treats them all is the same so they can all just be tables to
you but underneath the hood some of them are like hot tables and redshift and some of them are more cold tables in s3
